conclusion: Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium with a higher refractive index to a medium with a lower refractive index, and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.

The critical angle is given by sin(theta_c) = n2/n1, where n1 is the refractive index of the medium from which the light is coming (glass), and n2 is the refractive index of the medium into which the light is going (air).
Let n_a and n_b be the refractive indices of the glass for lights a and b, respectively.
Since light b undergoes TIR first, it implies that the critical angle for light b is smaller than that for light a, meaning n_b > n_a.
Both lights a and b enter the prism perpendicularly to the hypotenuse, so their initial angles of incidence inside the prism are zero.
As the angle of incidence is gradually increased, the light rays will start to bend more towards the normal due to refraction.
Since n_b > n_a, light b will bend more towards the normal compared to light a when they exit the prism.
Light b will reach the critical angle for TIR before light a does because it has a higher refractive index and thus a smaller critical angle.
Given that light b has a higher refractive index and therefore a smaller critical angle, it will indeed undergo total internal reflection first when the angle of incidence is gradually increased.
